Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multifunctional Nanocomposites with Reversible Switch and Controlled Release Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objective and Approach
This research is a fundamental study on surface switching and self-cleaning/release mechanisms and the development of new design concepts for manufacturing nanocomposite-based switchable surfaces. In this project, new multifunctional nanomaterials with surface switching, self-cleaning and controlled release on demand will be created. The nanocomposite materials and the associated surface dynamic behavior will be characterized quantitatively at the nanoscale. In addition, a multiscale modeling at atomistic and micromechanics scales is proposed to interpret experimental results and to address how the physical, chemical and structural properties of nanomaterials can be translated into enhanced switching performance. The modeling and experiment will be integrated to link the nanoscale phenomena to macroscopic performance.

Benefits to society
If successful, the benefits of this research will include a fundamental understanding of switching mechanisms for the design and development of optimized materials with better performance of practical significance. The success of the project will also advance a large variety of other applications, ranging from simple consumer products to complex technological systems with surface switching and self-cleaning/release properties. This collaborative research effort will impact the scientific and industrial communities to understand an array of materials and surface technologies. The major research outcome of this project is a technical platform for the development of next generation switchable surfaces. Furthermore, both undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in emerging and interdisciplinary research. Research and education efforts will be disseminated through conference presentations and scholarly publications that will be beneficial to the scientific community and our society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As we originally proposed, the major goal of this project is to develop new multifunctional nanomaterials with surface switching, self-cleaning and controlled release capabilities. Specifically, we have developed vertically-aligned carbon nanotube arrays (VA-CNTs) with various structures (e.g., different diameters, lengths, packing densities). By infiltrating poly(acrylic acid) hydrogel (PAA gel) into the VA-CNTs, we created electro-responsive surfaces. Although the direct electric-field stimulus was demonstrated to induce swellings of PAA gel, PAA gel showed stronger and faster responses (e.g., volume expansion and contraction) to pH changes. Therefore, we have also explored the possibilities to use the electric stimulus to tune the pH by electro-hydrolyzing water using the constituent CNTs in a VA-CNT array as nano-electrodes in an electrochemical cell. The strong and fast response to the electric-field stimulus was achieved through the local pH changes induced by a voltage (e.g., 5V) applied onto the CNT electrodes, and the associated surface dynamic behavior was characterized quantitatively at the nanoscale. In addition, a multiscale modeling at atomistic and micromechanics scales was developed to interpret experimental results and to address how the physical, chemical and structural properties of nanomaterials can be translated into enhanced switching performance. Furthermore, we have developed flexible and wearable wire-shaped microsupercapacitors based on highly aligned titania and carbon nanotubes, and aligned nanofibers from polypyrrole/graphene as electrodes for regeneration of optic nerve via electrical stimulation.

On the basis of these experimental and theoretical studies, we have published more than 20 journal publications, including Sci. Adv. (2), Chem. Rev. (1), Acc. Chem. Res. (1), Adv. Mater. (1), Angew. Chem. (2), JACS (1), ACS Nano (1), and Nano Energy (1) papers. Our work has also received numerous commentaries appeared in scientific, business, and popular press (please see: “Events & News” at http://case.edu/cse/eche/daigroup/index.html). This project has led to not only a strong fundamental understanding of new scientific principles for the stimuli-responsive surface, but also innovative approaches to new multifunctional nanomaterials with surface switching, self-cleaning and controlled release capabilities for various applications, ranging from wearable electronics through smart sensing/control release to electrical stimulation of nerves.

The education impact includes the creation of an environment where all-level students (graduate, undergraduate, high school, and students from underrepresented groups) from multidisciplinary background work together on the development of a common platform. A special effort has been made to encourage participation of student(s) from under-represented groups. Indeed, three female undergraduate students, Miss Heather Froggatt, Michel’le Wright, and Qian Liu have actively participated in the project at CWRU during this summer. Miss Janice Baek, a high school student who had actively participated in the project at CWRU during last summer, has been admitted to UIUC through an early action. Another female high school student, Miss Alice Jin, has received award from the Northeastern Ohio Science and Engineering Fair, and the John Bell Memorial Award from the Society for Applied Spectroscopy. Miss Jin was admitted to Harvard through an early action.


Last Modified: 09/26/2016
Modified by: Liming Dai
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: As we originally proposed, the major goal of this project is to develop new multifunctional nanomaterials with surface switching, self-cleaning and controlled release capabilities. Specifically, we have developed vertically-aligned carbon nanotube arrays (VA-CNTs) with various structures (e.g., different diameters, lengths, packing densities). Although the direct electric-field stimulus was demonstrated to induce swellings of PAA gel, PAA gel showed stronger and faster responses (e.g., volume expansion and contraction) to pH changes. Therefore, we have also explored the possibilities to use the electric stimulus to tune the pH by electro-hydrolyzing water using the constituent CNTs in a VA-CNT array as nano-electrodes in an electrochemical cell. The strong and fast response to the electric-field stimulus was achieved through the local pH changes induced by a voltage (e.g., 5V) applied onto the CNT electrodes, and the associated surface dynamic behavior was characterized quantitatively at the nanoscale. In addition, a multiscale modeling at atomistic and micromechanics scales was developed to interpret experimental results and to address how the physical, chemical and structural properties of nanomaterials can be translated into enhanced switching performance. Furthermore, we have developed flexible and wearable wire-shaped microsupercapacitors based on highly aligned titania and carbon nanotubes, and aligned nanofibers from polypyrrole/graphene as electrodes for regeneration of optic nerve via electrical stimulation. On the basis of these experimental and theoretical studies, we have published more than 20 journal publications, including Sci. Adv. (2), Chem. Rev. (1), Acc. Chem. Res. (1), Adv. Mater. (1), Angew. Chem. (2), JACS (1), ACS Nano (1), and Nano Energy (1) papers. Our work has also received numerous commentaries appeared in scientific, business, and popular press (please see: "Events & News" at http://case.edu/cse/eche/daigroup/index.html). This project has led to not only a strong fundamental understanding of new scientific principles for the stimuli-responsive surface, but also innovative approaches to new multifunctional nanomaterials with surface switching, self-cleaning and controlled release capabilities for various applications, ranging from wearable electronics through smart sensing/control release to electrical stimulation of nerves. The education impact includes the creation of an environment where all-level students (graduate, undergraduate, high school, and students from underrepresented groups) from multidisciplinary background work together on the development of a common platform. A special effort has been made to encourage participation of student(s) from under-represented groups. Indeed, three female undergraduate students, Miss Heather Froggatt, Michel?le Wright, and Qian Liu have actively participated in the project at CWRU during this summer. Miss Janice Baek, a high school student who had actively participated in the project at CWRU during last summer, has been admitted to UIUC through an early action. Another female high school student, Miss Alice Jin, has received award from the Northeastern Ohio Science and Engineering Fair, and the John Bell Memorial Award from the Society for Applied Spectroscopy.
